dc:description:
FGFR3 was first reported in relation to semidominant camptodactyly-tall stature-scoliosis-hearing loss (CATSHL) syndrome in 2006 (Toydemir et al., PMID: 17033969). CATSHL syndrome shows a continuum of disorder with more severe phenotypes in biallelic cases, and less severe phenotypes in monoallelic cases. 2 missense variants are associated with CATSHL syndrome and have been reported in 3 probands in
3 publications (PMIDs: 17033969, 27139183, 24864036). When inherited monoallelically, the missense variants might form heterodimers with wild type FGFR3 protein, inhibiting kinase activity needed for normal activation and binding to regulate bone growth, ultimately leading to a dominant negative LOF mechanism pathogenicity (Toydemir et al. 2006; PMID: 17033969). This gene-disease association is also supported by 2 mouse models and a zebrafish model (PMIDs: 8601314, 8630492, 32641982). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Skeletal Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date 3/2/22 (SOP Version 8).

FGFR3 was first reported in relation to semidominant camptodactyly-tall stature-scoliosis-hearing loss (CATSHL) syndrome in 2006 (Toydemir et al., PMID: 17033969). CATSHL syndrome shows a continuum of disorder with more severe phenotypes in biallelic cases, and less severe phenotypes in monoallelic cases. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found differences in phenotypic variability. Therefore, the following disease entities have been split into multiple disease entities, SADDAN (OMIM:616482), Hypochondroplasia (OMIM:146000), Achondroplasia (OMIM: 100800), *FGFR3*-related Thanatophoric Dysplasia (Type I OMIM:187600 and Type II OMIM:187601), Crouzon Syndrome with acanthosis nigricans (OMIM:612247), Muenke Syndrome (OMIM:602849), and CATSHL Syndrome (OMIM:610474). The split curations for these gene disease relationships have been curated separately. 2 missense variants are associated with CATSHL syndrome and have been reported in 3 probands in 3 publications (PMIDs: 17033969, 27139183, 24864036). When inherited monoallelically, the missense variants might form heterodimers with wild type FGFR3 protein, inhibiting kinase activity needed for normal activation and binding to regulate bone growth, ultimately leading to a dominant negative LOF mechanism pathogenicity (Toydemir et al. 2006; PMID: 17033969). This gene-disease association is also supported by 2 mouse models and a zebrafish model (PMIDs: 8601314, 8630492, 32641982). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Skeletal Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date 3/2/22 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: This mouse model shows similar severe skeletal phenotypes as mentioned previously in Deng et al. (PMID: 8601314), but also details the severe ear abnormalities, which recapitulates the hearing loss seen in human patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: Colvin Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Recapitulates skeletal phenotypes but not auditory/HL phenotypes.
This model recapitulates the skeletal findings seen in human patients, but lacks the hearing loss phenoypes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Deng Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded for partial recapitulation of human phenotypes.
This model partially recapitulates phenotypes seen in human patients: microcephaly and hearing loss.
evidence.rdfs:label: Sun Zebrafish Model
Makrythanasis Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: severe lateral deviation, deformity and anterior and lateral bowing of leg bones, genu valgum, prominent joints and lateral displacement of patellae, height of +4.0 SD, OFC -2 SD, excessive length of limbs. Sensorineural HL, bilateral camptodactyly of 5th finger, hyperextension. Radiographs: thin, long lower limb bones, deformed bowed tibiae and fibulae, arachnodactyly, wormian bones and increased pneumatisation of sinuses on skull, thoracic scoliosis.

evidence.dc:description: Radiographs provide phenotypic impact of variant.

evidence.rdfs:label: Escobar Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Birth length in 97th centile, multiple finger contractures in childhood, progressive sensorineural HL, tibial stress fractures at 8 and 10 yrs, scoliosis at 12 yrs.
At 16 yrs: height in 90th centile, OFC was -2SD. Long, thin, and contracted fingers, mild scoliosis, genu valgum, leg length discrepancy of 1.6 cm with the left being longer than the right.
Radiographs: right coxa valga of the right femoral neck, right femoral head laterally displaced with 30% uncovering, left femoral head medially displaced.
Positive family history: affected father (HL, ruptured vertebral discs, camptodactyly, height >97th centile), paternal grandfather (HL and camptodactyly), and his mother (no specific phenotype information given). No confirmation that these family members were genotyped.

evidence.rdfs:label: Makrythanasis Family
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Standard CATSHL phenotypes, more severe in older brother, less severe in younger brother, indicating progressive nature. Mother and father are mildly affected with slight tall stature, relative microcephaly, and long lower limbs.

evidence.dc:description: Genome-wide linkage scan, then direct DNA sequencing of FGFR3 in 20 affected individuals.
evidence.rdfs:label: Toydemir Family

member.rdfs:label: Toydemir Proband
member.detectionMethod: genome-wide linkage scan, then direct DNA sequencing of 20 affected individuals
member.phenotypeFreeText:
Height of males: >97th percentile (in 5 of 5); Height of females: >97th percentile (in 8 of 9). Camptodactyly of the hands and/or feet in 18 of 20, HL in 17 of 20. Dev. delay in 12 of 20, several had scoliosis and/or a pectus excavatum. 
Radiographs: tall vertebral bodies with irregular borders, broad femoral metaphyses with long tubular shafts, several had single osteochondroma of femur, tibia, or phalanx, pectus abnormalities and/or severe thoracolumbar kyphoscoliosis.
Marfan Syndrome, LADD excluded.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Height of males: >97th percentile (in 5 of 5); Height of females: >97th percentile (in 8 of 9). Camptodactyly of the hands and/or feet in 18 of 20, HL in 17 of 20. Dev. delay in 12 of 20, several had scoliosis and/or a pectus excavatum. 
Radiographs: tall vertebral bodies with irregular borders, broad femoral metaphyses with long tubular shafts, several had single osteochondroma of femur, tibia, or phalanx, pectus abnormalities and/or severe thoracolumbar kyphoscoliosis.
Marfan Syndrome, LADD excluded.

evidence.dc:description: Radiographs showed phenotypic impact of variant in this case.
